biases.name: Confirmation Bias
biases.description: The tendency to search for, interpret, and recall information in a way that confirms one's preexisting beliefs or hypotheses.
examples: This proves what I've been saying all along
I knew this would happen
I only read news sources that align with my views
patterns: I only listen to (sources|people) that make sense

biases.name: Anchoring Bias
biases.description: The tendency to rely too heavily on the first piece of information encountered (the 'anchor') when making decisions.
examples: The first price I saw was $100, so this seems like a good deal.
She said it was worth $1,000, so that's stuck in my head.

biases.name: Availability Heuristic
biases.description: Overestimating the likelihood of events based on how easily examples come to mind.
examples: Plane crashes are so common
I heard of someone getting robbed last week, it's getting worse
patterns: (seems|feels) like this happens (a lot|all the time)
must be common because I can think of examples

biases.name: Bandwagon Effect
biases.description: The tendency to adopt beliefs or behaviors because many others do the same.
examples: Everyone is investing in crypto
All my friends think this is true

biases.name: Negativity Bias
biases.description: The tendency to give more weight to negative experiences or information than positive ones.
examples: One bad review among dozens of good ones makes me doubt the product
I had one bad experience so I'll never go back
patterns: remember the criticism more than praise

biases.name: Dunning-Kruger Effect
biases.description: When people with limited knowledge or competence in a given domain greatly overestimate their own knowledge or competence.
examples: How hard could it be? I could do that easily
I read an article about this so I know as much as experts
patterns: doesn't take much to understand this

biases.name: Sunk Cost Fallacy
biases.description: Continuing a behavior or endeavor due to previously invested resources (time, money, effort) despite new evidence suggesting it's no longer worthwhile.
examples: I've already spent so much on this project, I can't quit now
We've been together for five years, I can't break up now
patterns: too much invested to walk away

biases.name: Halo Effect
biases.description: The tendency for positive impressions in one area to influence opinion in another area.
examples: He's attractive so he must be smart too
That company makes great phones so their new laptop must be good
patterns: good at one thing means good at others
successful in (business|sports) so must be right about

biases.name: In-Group Bias
biases.description: The tendency to favor one's own group and its members over outsiders.
examples: People from my country are more honest
Our team's fans are more passionate

biases.name: Optimism Bias
biases.description: The tendency to overestimate the likelihood of positive events and underestimate the likelihood of negative events.
examples: I won't get sick
It won't happen to me
My startup will succeed while others fail
patterns: those statistics don't apply to me
I have a good feeling about this

biases.name: Hindsight Bias
biases.description: The tendency to perceive past events as having been predictable, despite having little or no objective basis for predicting them.
examples: I knew that team would win
I could have predicted the market would crash

biases.name: Authority Bias
biases.description: The tendency to attribute greater accuracy to the opinion of an authority figure and be more influenced by that opinion.
examples: My doctor said it, so it must be right
The CEO thinks this is the best approach
patterns: they have a title so they must be right

biases.name: Attentional Bias
biases.description: The tendency to pay attention to some things while simultaneously ignoring others.
examples: I only notice the red cars on the road
I keep seeing ads for products I recently looked at

biases.name: Belief Bias
biases.description: The tendency to evaluate the logical strength of an argument based on whether you believe the conclusion rather than how well the conclusion follows from the premises.
examples: That can't be right because it doesn't match what I believe
The logic must be flawed because the conclusion seems wrong
patterns: logic must be flawed because conclusion is wrong
doesn't match my understanding so it's incorrect
sounds wrong so the reasoning must be off

biases.name: Curse of Knowledge
biases.description: When better-informed people find it difficult to think about problems from the perspective of lesser-informed people.
examples: It's so obvious, I don't understand why you don't get it
Everyone knows how this works

biases.name: Fundamental Attribution Error
biases.description: The tendency to attribute others' behaviors to their character or personality while attributing one's own behavior to circumstances.
examples: He's late because he's disorganized, but I'm late because there was traffic
They failed because they didn't try hard enough

biases.name: Just-World Hypothesis
biases.description: The belief that people get what they deserve and deserve what they get.
examples: They must have done something to deserve that
Hard work always pays off eventually
patterns: must have done something to deserve

biases.name: Loss Aversion
biases.description: The tendency to prefer avoiding losses to acquiring equivalent gains.
examples: I'd rather not lose $100 than gain $100
I'll keep this stock until it gets back to what I paid for it
patterns: hate losing more than love winning
keep until I get back to what I paid

biases.name: Overconfidence Bias
biases.description: Excessive confidence in one's own answers, predictions or abilities.
examples: I'm certain I'm right about this
I'm definitely going to finish this by tomorrow

biases.name: Planning Fallacy
biases.description: The tendency to underestimate the time, costs, and risks of future actions and overestimate the benefits.
examples: This project will only take two weeks
I can easily prepare for the exam in one night

biases.name: Projection Bias
biases.description: The tendency to unconsciously assume that others share the same or similar thoughts, beliefs, values, or positions.
examples: Everyone thinks this way
Anyone would feel the same in my position

biases.name: Recency Bias
biases.description: The tendency to place more importance on recent events than historic ones.
examples: The stock has gone up the last three days, so it will continue rising
My last workout was great, so I'm in good shape

biases.name: Self-Serving Bias
biases.description: The tendency to attribute positive events to one's own character but attribute negative events to external factors.
examples: I got the promotion because I deserved it
I failed the test because it was unfair
patterns: my success is earned, my failures are bad luck
take credit for wins but not losses

biases.name: Spotlight Effect
biases.description: The tendency to overestimate how much others notice about you.
examples: Everyone noticed my mistake
People will judge my outfit

biases.name: Status Quo Bias
biases.description: The preference for things to stay the same.
examples: I'll just stick with what I know
Better the devil you know than the devil you don't
patterns: prefer to keep things as they are

fallacies.name: Ad Hominem
fallacies.description: Attacking your opponent's character or personal traits instead of engaging with their argument.
examples: You're too young to understand this
He's biased because he works for them

fallacies.name: Appeal to Authority
fallacies.description: Using the opinion or position of an authority figure as evidence in your argument.
examples: A scientist said it's true
The CEO believes it, so it must be right

fallacies.name: Appeal to Emotion
fallacies.description: Manipulating an emotional response in place of a valid or compelling argument.
examples: Think of the children!
If you care about people, you'll agree with me

fallacies.name: Appeal to Nature
fallacies.description: Arguing that because something is 'natural' it is therefore good, valid, justified, or better.
examples: It's natural, so it must be good for you
Humans aren't meant to eat processed foods
patterns: that's how it is in nature

fallacies.name: Appeal to Tradition
fallacies.description: Arguing that because something is older or traditional it is therefore better.
examples: This is how we've always done it
Traditional values have stood the test of time

fallacies.name: Bandwagon Fallacy
fallacies.description: Arguing that because lots of people do something or believe something, it must be valid, true, or good.
examples: Everyone is doing it
Most people believe this, so it must be true

fallacies.name: Begging the Question
fallacies.description: A circular argument in which the conclusion is included in the premise.
examples: This law is unjust because it's unfair
I'm right because I say so

fallacies.name: Black-or-White Fallacy
fallacies.description: Presenting two alternative options as the only possibilities, when in fact more possibilities exist.
examples: Either you're with us or against us
America: love it or leave it

fallacies.name: Burden of Proof
fallacies.description: Saying that the burden of proof lies not with the person making the claim, but with someone else to disprove.
examples: Prove that ghosts don't exist
I know this works, prove me wrong

fallacies.name: Composition/Division
fallacies.description: Assuming that what's true for a part is true for the whole, or that what's true for the whole is true for a part.
examples: Every player on the team is excellent, so the team is excellent
That company has problems, so all its employees must be problematic
patterns: every (part|member|player) is, so the whole is
what's true of one is true of all
applies to the whole so applies to each part

fallacies.name: False Cause
fallacies.description: Presuming that a real or perceived relationship between things means that one is the cause of the other.
examples: I wore my lucky socks and we won
Crime rates have dropped while ice cream sales increased
patterns: happened after, so happened because of
when X, also Y, therefore X causes Y

fallacies.name: Fallacy Fallacy
fallacies.description: Presuming a claim is false because an argument for it contains a fallacy.
examples: Your argument contains a fallacy, so your conclusion must be wrong
You used an appeal to emotion, so you must be incorrect
patterns: your argument (contains|has) a fallacy, so your conclusion is wrong
you used (bad logic|a fallacy), so you're incorrect

fallacies.name: Genetic Fallacy
fallacies.description: Judging something as good or bad based on where it comes from or who said it.
examples: That research comes from a biased institution
I don't trust anything from that news source
patterns: comes from (a biased|an untrustworthy|a questionable) source

fallacies.name: Middle Ground Fallacy
fallacies.description: Assuming that a compromise or middle position between two extremes must be correct.
examples: Some say climate change is a crisis, others say it's not happening, so the truth must be somewhere in between
Both sides have valid points, so the answer is in the middle
patterns: truth must be somewhere in between

fallacies.name: No True Scotsman
fallacies.description: Making what could be called an appeal to purity as a way to dismiss relevant criticisms or flaws in your argument.
examples: No true Christian would do that
Real fans never criticize the team
patterns: if you were a genuine (X), you wouldn't
anyone who really understands would agree

fallacies.name: Personal Incredulity
fallacies.description: Saying that because you can't understand or imagine how something could be true, it must be false.
examples: I can't understand how evolution works, so it must be false
That's too complex to be real
patterns: doesn't make sense to me, so must be wrong

fallacies.name: Special Pleading
fallacies.description: Moving the goalposts or making up exceptions when a claim is shown to be false.
examples: All psychics can read minds, but not when there are skeptics around
The rules apply to everyone except me
patterns: normally works, just not this time

fallacies.name: Slippery Slope
fallacies.description: Asserting that if we allow A to happen, then Z will eventually happen too, therefore A should not happen.
examples: If we allow same-sex marriage, next people will marry animals
If we ban assault rifles, soon all guns will be illegal
patterns: if we allow (A), next (B) will happen

fallacies.name: Strawman
fallacies.description: Misrepresenting someone's argument to make it easier to attack.
examples: You want open borders, which means letting criminals in
You're against this policy, so you don't care about children
patterns: you're against (X), so you don't care about

fallacies.name: The Texas Sharpshooter
fallacies.description: Cherry-picking data clusters to suit an argument, or finding a pattern to fit a presumption.
examples: Look at these cancer clusters near power lines
These three events prove my theory

fallacies.name: Tu Quoque
fallacies.description: Avoiding having to engage with criticism by turning it back on the accuser - answering criticism with criticism.
examples: You criticize pollution but you drive a car
The company criticizing us has the same problems

fallacies.name: Ambiguity
fallacies.description: Using a double meaning or ambiguity of language to mislead or misrepresent the truth.
examples: I'm not going to stop promoting freedom of speech
The senator said he supports the troops

fallacies.name: Anecdotal Evidence
fallacies.description: Using personal experience or isolated examples instead of scientific evidence or statistical data.
examples: My grandfather smoked and lived to 100
I know someone who didn't study and passed the exam
patterns: happened to a friend of mine

fallacies.name: Appeal to Ignorance
fallacies.description: Claiming something is true because it hasn't been proven false, or vice versa.
examples: No one has proven God doesn't exist, so there must be a God
There's no evidence aliens don't visit Earth
patterns: no one has proven (X) doesn't exist

fallacies.name: Loaded Question
fallacies.description: Asking a question that has an assumption built into it so that it can't be answered without appearing guilty.
examples: Have you stopped lying to your parents?
When did your company stop polluting the river?
